remarks: Principle of transitive induction, finite version.  The first three hypotheses give various existences, the next three give necessary substitutions and the last two are the basis and the induction hypothesis.  (Contributed by Drahflow, 12-Nov-2015.)
statement:
relexpind.1 $e |- ( et -> Rel R ) $.
relexpind.2 $e |- ( et -> R e. _V ) $.
relexpind.3 $e |- ( et -> S e. _V ) $.
relexpind.4 $e |- ( et -> X e. _V ) $.
relexpind.5 $e |- ( i = S -> ( ph <-> ch ) ) $.
relexpind.6 $e |- ( i = x -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
relexpind.7 $e |- ( i = j -> ( ph <-> th ) ) $.
relexpind.8 $e |- ( x = X -> ( ps <-> ta ) ) $.
relexpind.9 $e |- ( et -> ch ) $.
relexpind.10 $e |- ( et -> ( j R x -> ( th -> ps ) ) ) $.
relexpind $p |- ( et -> ( n e. NN0 -> ( S ( R ^r n ) X -> ta ) ) ) $.
$d R i j x $.
$d S i j x $.
$d X x $.
$d ch i $.
$d et i j x $.
$d i j ps $.
$d i th $.
$d j ph x $.
$d n x $.
$d ta x $.
